 There's something big over here!" shouted Allison. We gathered around her find, a blackened, fossilized skull fragment more than a foot across. After puzzling over the piece briefly, I declared "It's a cow, a fossilized cow skull." 
 
 Now what was a fossil cow skull doing in a place like this - an area rich in dinosaur bone more than 100 million years old?
 
 More pieces of the puzzle were being picked up by other team members. Dave exclaimed gleefully, "Look, it's human! Part of the skull!" as he held high the curved plate of bone that shields the massive human brain. He never expected to find fossil humans on a dinosaur expedition

I would also love a explanation of this global flood, given that evolution is a 'myth'.
 
 The ark being comparable with the size of an american football pitch, how did Noah fit in the millions of species of animal we see on earth today (even discounting those that live in water)? Also, it does not specify how much warning Noah was given before the flood waters came, but presumably it would have been time enough to visit Australia (for kangaroos, koalas etc), America (for opossums), the Arctic (for polar bears), and the Antarctic (for penguins) and pretty much every other corner of the globe for other species.
 
 Once he had collected these millions of species (7 of each clean animal, and 2 for unclean), and they'd refrained from eating each other during their cruise, how did they survive? We get worried when current species get down to a few thousand breeding pairs. Would not 1 or 2 breeding pairs make the future of a species nigh on impossible.

ShadowPikachu

The ark being comparable with the size of an american football pitch, how did Noah fit in the millions of species of animal we see on earth today (even discounting those that live in water)? Also, it does not specify how much warning Noah was given before the flood waters came, but presumably it would have been time enough to visit Australia (for kangaroos, koalas etc), America (for opossums), the Arctic (for polar bears), and the Antarctic (for penguins) and pretty much every other corner of the globe for other species.
 

 
 Smiley, good points all, but you don't even have to go that far with the species argument. All you have to do is point out that the ark itself could not have survived any sort of water. I'll post what I said in another thread for everyone here:
 
A large wooden ship (as large as the ark) would break up. It is not due to the design. 
 
 The basic limiting factor is the Modulus of Elasticity (stress/strain). Wood's limit tops out around 2,000,000 pounds per square inch. Steel is nearly 15 to 16 times that. With the weight of the cargo pushing down, and the water pressure pushing up, the wooden structure flexes 15 times as much as steel. The gaps between the planks would become huge, causing leaking and failure.
 
 Wood also absorbs water and loses strength. The nails fastening it together would undergo the flexing, creating holes that become wider and wider until they fall out. It might technically be possible to build a wooden ship as large as the ark, however, it would be filled entirely with internal structure to support it, and there would be no cargo space whatsoever.

 
 It might be possible to have a wooden ship the size of the ark, but you wouldn't be able to do anything with it.

 And about Ernst Mayr: 
 
 SS: Ernst Mayr even admits that evolution doens't proceed by mutation
 
 Electro-loser: Not mutation alone; for you to represent Mayr as being anti-Darwinian is indicative of your affinity for dishonesty
 
 
 http://home.cfl.rr.com/jessehenson/ernstivw.html
 
 Ernst Mayr:
 
 When you have a good modern discussion of evolutionary factors, the word 'mutation' literally never appears because most genetic variation is produced by recombination and not by mutations. And what we say is that evolution is due to variation selection; we don't say any longer that it is due to mutation selection like we used to.
 
 Let's say you could stop the mutation process today. We could still have, potentially, evolution for 100s if not thousands of years because there's all the genetic variation in all the gene pools. You see, we've got 5 billion human individuals and, except for identical twins, they're all uniquely different. Through the recombination of existing gene pools, selection could go on 100s if not thousands of years even if you have no mutation. That's why it is important to distinguish between genetic variation and mutation. Thinking in terms of mutation is still a hangover of the old essentialist way of thinking: we had the previous essence, then we had the mutation, then there's the new essence. Since we had no previous essence, instead we had a variable population; it's completely misleading to talk so much about mutation.
 
 So do you like misleading people, electro-loser? It's probably best you just don't debate me.
pandion

Ernst Mayr:
Do you make an effort to misunderstand? Or maybe it is an intentional effort to deceive.
electrolyte

The nylon bug is not random, genius. Try again.

 Support your assertion. Merely saying that I'm wrong is what you always do, and you never back it up in any sense of sufficiency.
 
 
So do you like misleading people... ?

 Me? Let's take a look at what he says, in light of his views:
 
 "... most genetic variation is produced by recombination and not by mutations."
 Here Mayr was talking about "variation" as different combinations of genes existing in the same individual, not new (i.e. previously nonexistent) or altered genes. He made this clear when he said, that "[w]e could still have, potentially, evolution for 100s if not thousands of years because there's all the genetic variation in all the gene pools" even if mutations were stopped. Mayr emphasized this more than most people probably would because of his profound appreciation for epistatic effects. 
 
 My statement was in no way misleading, dishonest, or incorrect (except perhaps that I should have said anti-neoDarwinian instead of anti-Darwinian, despite the fact that sport throws around the latter in place of the former. Hell, Mayr was a major contributor to the modern synthesis). Mayr's explanation is in agreement with the standard modern definition of evolution: change in allele frequencies over generations. If the relative frequency of alleles for green eyes increases (or decreases, or reaches unity, or reaches extinction), that's evolution, and without mutation; surely nobody believes that everybody with an allele for green eyes obtained that allele via mutation. How that allele (and others arose), on the other hand, is not explained by recombination. Mayr goes on to say that these should be recognized as distinct; supersport seems to imply that Mayr thinks that mutations are evolutionarily unimportant.
 
 If sport would care to read any books by Mayr-- oh, who am I kidding? He'd never do that.
